definitions.definition: to reach the standard of ability or knowledge needed to do a particular job, for example by completing a course of study or passing exams

examples.text: How long does it take to qualify?
He qualified as a doctor last year.
She spent seven years qualifying in law.

definitions.definition: to give somebody the skills and knowledge they need to do something
definitions.sensetop: qualify somebody for somethingqualify somebody to do something

examples.text: This training course will qualify you for a better job.
The test qualifies you to drive heavy vehicles.

definitions.definition: to be of a high enough standard to enter a competition; to defeat another person or team in order to enter or continue in a competition

examples.text: He failed to qualify.
South Korea **qualified for the finals** when they beat Italy 6–1.
They qualified for the World Cup.

definitions.definition: to have or give somebody the right to do something
definitions.sensetop: qualify for somethingqualify somebodyqualify somebody for something

examples.text: To qualify, you must have lived in this country for at least three years.
If you live in the area, you qualify for a parking permit.
In order to qualify for scholarships, students must demonstrate potential for academic excellence.
Your educational background, interests and family history are some of the things that might qualify you.
Paying a fee doesn't automatically qualify you for membership.
You will automatically qualify for a pension.
people who qualify for the grant on the grounds of disability
Membership of the scheme qualifies you for the discount.
You have to be over 60 to qualify.

definitions.definition: to have the right qualities to be described as a particular thing

examples.text: Do you think this dress qualifies as evening wear?
It's an old building, but that doesn't qualify it as an ancient monument!

definitions.definition: to add something to a previous statement to make the meaning less strong or less general

examples.text: I want to qualify what I said earlier—I didn't mean he couldn't do the job, only that he would need supervision.

definitions.definition: to describe another word in a particular way

examples.text: In ‘the open door’, ‘open’ is an adjective qualifying ‘door’.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘describe in a particular way’): from French qualifier, from medieval Latin qualificare, from Latin qualis ‘of what kind, of such a kind’ (see quality).
